procedure: Left intertrochanteric femoral fracture open reduction internal fixation
Planned operative fixation of left intertrochanteric femoral fracture
extracted_info.summary: 86-year-old male with severely comminuted left intertrochanteric femoral fracture after a fall. Patient has significant medical comorbidities including CAD, A-fib, and recent left inguinal hernia repair. Patient was on Plavix but it was held post-surgery. After discussion of risks and benefits, patient has elected to proceed with surgical fixation.
diagnosis: Severely comminuted left intertrochanteric femoral fracture
Coronary artery disease status post stents
History of bacteremia due to group B Streptococcus
key_information: Patient on Plavix for CAD but currently holding post-surgery
Patient has diffuse wounds and ulcerations across lower legs in various stages of healing
High surgical risk due to age and comorbidities
Patient was ambulatory prior to fall
Patient has history of right total hip arthroplasty in 2015
Patient has venous insufficiency which may impact healing
Patient has history of infections including ESBL and bacteremia
Shortened and externally rotated left leg noted on exam
Patient and son informed of high risk nature of surgery including possibility of death

procedure: Left intertrochanteric femoral fracture open reduction internal fixation
extracted_info.summary: 86-year-old male presented after a mechanical fall with a displaced left intertrochanteric femur fracture. Patient underwent open reduction internal fixation using an Arthrex short nail with lag screw, antirotation screw, and interlocking screws. Postoperatively, the patient will be partial weight bearing (50%) for 6 weeks with DVT prophylaxis and progressive mobilization.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. Location: Greenwich Hospital

Procedure: Left intertrochanteric femoral fracture open reduction internal fixaion
Preliminary Diagnosis: Left Intertrochanteric Femur Fracture, displaced
Postoperative Diagnosis: Left Intertrochanteric Femur Fracture, displaced
Surgeon: Dr. Kevin Choo

First Assist: None

Anesthesia Type: General with LMA

Indication:

The patient is a 86 y.o. male who was brought to Greenwich Hospital Emergency Department after a mechanical fall
after which the patient was unable to bear weight. X rays in the emergency room demonstrated evidence of a
displaced femoral fracture. Given the nature of the injury, a discussion regarding the risks associated with and the
alternatives to surgery were discussed. This discussion included the potential complications of deep venous
thrombosis, infection, nerve or blood vessel injury, ligament injury, dislocation, leg length discrepancy, fracture, mal-
or non-union, and incomplete resolution of pain, the patient wished to proceed with open reduction internal fixation of
the intertrochanteric femur.

Procedure:

The patient was brought to the Operating Room and after the successful induction of general/LMA anesthesia, a
closed reduction was performed. Flouroscopy was used to confirm that the reduction was within acceptable

Wallace, William F (MRN MR71970) Printed by Stagno, Cesarina [767] at 10/29/2025 11:22 AM

10/29/25, 11:22 AM Wallace, William F (MR # MR71970) DOB: 12/15/1938

parameters.The lower extremity was then prepped and draped in the usual sterile manner with the patient in the
supine position on the fracture table. Prophylactic antibiotics were administered within 30 minutes prior to the
procedure as well as 1 gram of tranexamic acid. A time out was performed by all members of the surgical team
confirming patient identity and surgical site laterality.

A lateral incision was made proximal to, and in-line with, the femur. The entry guidewire was then advanced onto the
appropriate start site on the greater trochanter. This was confirmed with intraoperative flouroscopy on both the AP
and lateral views. The guidewire was then advanced with power into the intramedullary canal. Again flouroscopy was
used to confirm that the entry guidewire was in the appropriate position. The entry reamer was then used through the
soft tissue protector canula. Flouroscopy was used to confirm appropriate position of the entry reamer within the
intramedullary canal and that it had been advanced to a sufficient depth. The reamer and entry guidewire were then
removed.

The nail was then carefully advanced over the guidewire. During advancement of the nail, all reduction maneuvers
were employed to maintain the reduction during insertion of the nail. Flouroscopy was again used to confirm that the
nail had been advanced to the appropriate depth. The long guidewire was then removed. An incision was made over
the lateral aspect of the thigh and the cannula for the lag screw was advanced until it made contact with the lateral
cortical bone. Using flouroscopic guidance, the guidewire for the lag screw was then inserted and confirmed to be in
appropriate position with the guidwire center-center on AP and lateral views of the femoral head. The depth of the
guidewire was then measured and the 105 mm lag screw selected. The guidewire was then overdrilled and tapped
for the screw of the appropriate depth. The lag screw was then inserted to the appropriate depth which again
confirmed using flouroscopy. Similarly the anti rotation screw also placed in the standard fashion.

We then turned our attention to insertion of the distal interlocking screws. Two small incisions made over the lateral
thigh in line with the cannula for the distal interlocking screw. The cannula was then advanced through the incision
and down to bone. The drill was then carefully advanced and the depth of the interlocking screw measured off of the
drill. The screws of appropriate length was then inserted. Flouroscopy was again used to confirm that the screws
were in appropriate position.

The wounds were then copiously irrigated. The fascia was closed with interrupted 0 vicryl suture. The deep
subcutaneous layers were closed with interrupted 0 vicryl and the dermal layer with 3-0 vicryl. The skin was then
closed with staples. Sterile dressings were then applied and the patient was awaken from anesthesia. The patient
was transferred to the recovery room in stable condition. All sponge and instrument counts were correct.

Postop Plan

The patient will be partial weight bearing (50% weight bearing for 6 weeks). DVT prophylaxis will be started on
POD1; additional DVT prophylaxis will include SCDs, compression stockings, progressive mobilization. They will
receive 24 hours of postoperative antibiotics. The patient will be discharged from the hospital when they are
medically stable, have met all PT goals, and their pain is well controlled with oral analgesia.

Kevin Choo, MD
